episodes.content: A pointed boulder with a large stone at its foot reaches for the heavens. The white gravel between them represents a swift flowing river, without the use of water. Karesansui is a unique dry-gardening style that developed in the 14th century from ascetic practices at Kyoto's Zen temples. Monks aim for enlightenment within a world of rippling patterns that run between curious rock arrangements. Enter the infinite Zen cosmos through the Karesansui gardens at Tenryu-ji, Daisen-in and Ryoan-ji.
episodes.description: The ancient capital, Kyoto, continues to be innovative after 1,200 years. We dive deep into its core in this definitive program. Today: Karesansui, the Zen cosmos in a garden for spiritual training.
episodes.subtitle: Karesansui: The Zen Cosmos in a Garden for Spiritual Training
episodes.title: Core Kyoto

episodes.content: Kyoto confections are Wagashi, or traditional confections, infused with Kyoto's charm and influenced by the tea ceremony. With beautiful designs and names that subtly reflect the seasons, tea confections are an art form to be appreciated with the 5 senses. When making these confections, importance is placed on the semblance and name they are given. Inspiration is drawn from local nature, art, music and literature. Feel Japan's culture, nature and climate through flavorsome Kyoto confections.
episodes.description: The ancient capital, Kyoto, continues to be innovative after 1,200 years. We dive deep into its core. Today: Kyoto confections as experiencing Kyoto culture through the five senses.
episodes.subtitle: Kyoto Confections: Experiencing Kyoto Culture through the Five Senses
episodes.title: Core Kyoto

episodes.content: Filled with noble, graceful dignity, Kyoto dolls have long embodied people's prayers, relieved loneliness, and represented prayers for their children's growth. Connected to dynastic culture, these dolls evolved in the hands of talented Kyoto artisans. Edo-period craftsmen honed their doll-making skills, and these techniques are still practiced. Hina dolls reflect adoration for the nobility. Gosho dolls were adored at the palace. Find out how people's hearts are connected through Kyoto dolls.
episodes.description: The ancient capital, Kyoto, continues to be innovative after 1,200 years. We dive deep into its core in this definitive program. Today: Kyoto Dolls, adored by all, their grace brings peace.
episodes.subtitle: Kyoto Dolls: Adored by All, Their Grace Brings Peace
episodes.title: Core Kyoto

episodes.content: Kyoto is home to most Buddhist head temples, which shaped the ancient capital's historical landscape and fascinate visitors. Shichido-garan, the 7 most important buildings for Zen religious training, are positioned in the shape of a person. Maintaining temples for centuries, carpenters conduct major repairs at Chion-in and thatch Kiyomizu-dera's main-hall with cypress bark using traditional roofing methods. Look at the world of Buddhist architecture, sustained by craftsmanship and faith.
episodes.description: The ancient capital, Kyoto, continues to be innovative after 1,200 years. We dive deep into its core. Today: Buddhist Architecture, craftsmanship unites places of worship.
episodes.subtitle: Buddhist Architecture: Craftsmanship Unites Places of Worship
episodes.title: Core Kyoto

episodes.content: Ogres, specters, demons, ghosts and hell. The ancient capital's many myths of the spirit world seem fantastic today. Kyoto's citizens lived in fear and awe of the other world and appealed to the deities for help. They honored milestones and kept the annual events in thanks to the deities for their protection. Consequences of the city's prosperity, the legends have origins in the deep in the recesses of the human mind, and the epidemics and wars that occurred throughout Kyoto's history.
episodes.description: The ancient capital, Kyoto, continues to be innovative after 1,200 years. We dive deep into its core. Today: Legends of the spirit world that the mysterious inspires awe in the townsfolk.
episodes.subtitle: Legends of the Spirit World: The Mysterious Inspires Awe in the Townsfolk
episodes.title: Core Kyoto

episodes.content: At 3 a.m. on October 22, 2 large pine torches over 10m long are lit to signal the start of the fire festival at Iwakura Jinja. Long ago, it was believed that demons were contained by a huge boulder in the area, after which both the shrine and the area are named. In the late 1100's the shrine was built and the deity was transferred there, but it returns to the boulder on the day of the festival. Discover this 500-year-old festival through the preparations of the residents of Iwakura.
episodes.description: Today: Iwakura Fire Festival, the boulder's divine spirit returns. The ancient capital, Kyoto, continues to be innovative after 1,200 years. We dive deep into its core in this definitive program.
episodes.subtitle: Iwakura Fire Festival: The Divine Spirit Returns
episodes.title: Core Kyoto

episodes.content: Sento, or bathhouses, were built in Kyoto to cater to the large student and artisan population who lived in lodgings without baths. Many are worthy of historic note. One has been operating for 1,300 years; another is part of a temple complex. Some have splendid decors or interesting baths. Today they remain lively social hubs of their communities. A young manager strives to create a Sento young people frequent. Discover the allure of Sento where people gather to relieve the stress of the day.
episodes.description: Today: Public Baths where people gather to wash their troubles away. The ancient capital, Kyoto, continues to be innovative after 1,200 years. We dive deep into its core in this definitive program.
episodes.subtitle: Public Baths: People Gather to Wash Their Troubles Away
episodes.title: Core Kyoto

episodes.content: The "satoyama" style of living in harmony with nature, and the customs that influenced life in the ancient capital, survive in the mountains north of central Kyoto. An old inn in the town of Hanase continues to serve the local specialty, Tsumikusa (foraged wild foods) cuisine. Miyama is famous for its thatching tradition, and the local artisans use skills passed down for generations to re-thatch Kyoto's many temples and shrines. Discover the local customs that keep Kyoto's culture alive.
episodes.description: Today: Satoyama Living, country customs that sustain the ancient capital. Kyoto continues to be innovative after 1,200 years. We dive deep into its core in this definitive program.
episodes.subtitle: Satoyama Living: Country Customs Sustaining the Ancient Capital
episodes.title: Core Kyoto

episodes.content: Kyoto is dotted with Buddhist temples and Shinto shrines offering amulets for health, longevity, safety, easy childbirth and other blessings. An amulet warding off an epidemic centuries ago now eases Kyotoites' anxiety in the age of COVID-19. But amulets change with the times. A card that slips into a wallet and a microSD containing a Buddhist image for uploading to a mobile device keep the deities' spirits close by. Discover the charm of amulets through their history and their creation process.
episodes.description: Today: Kyoto Amulets, the embodiment of prayers for happiness. The ancient capital continues to be innovative 1,200 years after its foundation. We dive deep into its core in this definitive program.
episodes.subtitle: Kyoto Amulets: The Embodiment of Prayers for Happiness
episodes.title: Core Kyoto

episodes.content: Through novels and movies, the name Miyamoto Musashi has become synonymous with the word "samurai." The undefeated, 17th-century swordsman was also a master of calligraphy, the way of tea, and other arts. In his later years, he wrote "The Book of Five Rings" to relate the wisdom he gained through his duels. His teachings act a guide to living a significant life and remain seminal today during the pandemic. Discover Musashi's Kyoto through people who feel a deep affiliation with his way of life.
episodes.description: Miyamoto Musashi, master of the sword and the arts, wrote his teachings 400 years ago. They act as a guide to living a significant life and remain seminal today, especially during the pandemic.
episodes.subtitle: Miyamoto Musashi: Sword Mastery in the Ancient Capital
episodes.title: Core Kyoto

episodes.content: With the spread of Covid-19 in 2020, many annual festivals were condensed. But Kitano Goryoe was revived at Kitano Tenmangu after a 550-year hiatus in prayer for an end to the pandemic. The joint Shinto-Buddhist rite was originally held to appease the deity of plagues and honor dignitaries who were tragically killed. From this, Gion Matsuri and other festivals similarly evolved over the centuries. Discover the Kyoto customs to eradicate epidemics through rites, amulets, dolls, and confections.
episodes.description: Due to the 2020 pandemic, many annual festivals that originated to curb disease were condensed. Even with medical advances today, people turn to age-old customs for comfort and strength.
episodes.subtitle: Warding off Epidemics: Heartfelt Prayers for Safety
episodes.title: Core Kyoto

episodes.content: Solid, durable and decorative, lacquer is a lustrous, natural polymer used in art, architecture, Buddhist statues, and everyday items. Kyoto was the seat of the emperor and aristocratic culture, so lacquerers always strove to out-dazzle each other and, in the process, refined their workmanship. Undeterred by difficulties they face from the pandemic, lacquerers today continue the art while searching for fresh ideas. Discover how they create the unconventional and innovative within the traditional.
episodes.description: Solid, durable and decorative, lacquer is used in art, buildings, and everyday articles. Kyoto lacquerers strive to out-dazzle each other to create unconventional and innovative within the tradition.
episodes.subtitle: Nouveau Lacquerware: Vibrant, Dazzling Beauty
episodes.title: Core Kyoto
